conclusion: Ampere force is the force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field, calculated as F = BIL sinθ.
The wire is bent into a V-shape with an included angle of 60 degrees, and the magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the wire.
Consider the components of the force on each straight part of the wire and find the net force.
Each arm of the V should be l in length since the total length of the wire is 2l.
The force on each straight part should be in the direction perpendicular to both the magnetic field and the current direction.
Since the magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane, the angle between the current and the magnetic field is 90 degrees, so sinθ = 1.
The force on each straight part is F = BIL.
Consider the direction of the current in each arm relative to the magnetic field.
Each arm makes an angle of 30 degrees with the perpendicular bisector of the V.
The force is perpendicular to both the magnetic field and the current, so it should be in the plane.
Visualize the plane of the wire as the x-y plane, and the magnetic field along the z-axis.
The V-shape has two arms, each of length l, making a 60-degree angle at the vertex.
One arm is at 30 degrees to the x-axis, and the other at -30 degrees.
Consider the current direction in terms of vectors.
First arm: current vector I1 = I (l, 0). Second arm: current vector I2 = I (l/2, l√3/2).
The magnetic field B is perpendicular to the plane, so B = B (0, 0, 1).
The force on each segment is F = I * (L x B), where L is the vector along the wire segment.
